title: How to Win Tickets to Disneyland

steps.headline: Check Disney Parks’ official website regularly.
steps.description: Disney Parks periodically posts contest and sweepstakes, so bookmark https://disneyparks.disney.go.com on your web browser. Find the tab marked “Special Offers” to browse discounts and sweepstakes. You can also type keywords such as “Disneyland,” “contests,” and “sweepstakes” in the search bar.

steps.headline: Follow Disney Parks on social media.
steps.description: Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter are also great ways to find out about official Disney-sponsored giveaways. Just make sure the social media account you’re following is actually affiliated with Disney. It should be free of spelling and grammatical errors and have a blue verified check mark next to its name. Find a full list of official Disney Parks social media accounts at https://disneyparks.disney.go.com/social-media.

steps.headline: Check reputable websites that list contests every week.
steps.description: Websites such as MouseSavers.com compile current Disney contests and sweepstakes. Make sure any contest-listing websites you browse only list contests sponsored by Disney or a major corporation or organization. Check “About” pages for information about how websites vet their listings. Contest listings are typically updated weekly, so check back once a week.

steps.headline: Look for contests and offers on official tourism association websites.
steps.description: Official tourism associations frequently offer discounts and occasionally run contests. The official tourism association for Anaheim, CA, which is where Disneyland is located, is https://visitanaheim.org. You can also search for associations affiliated with other Disney park locations. Enter the location plus “official tourism association.” Check websites’ “About” sections to ensure they specify that they’re a city’s official tourism organization. Official tourism organization websites typically have a “Discounts” tab on the home page’s menu bar. You can also enter “special offer,” “contest,” or “sweepstakes” into the search bar.

steps.headline: Set up search engine alerts.
steps.description: You could search every day for giveaways sponsored by Disney, reputable websites, travel companies, or local TV and radio stations. However, setting up a search alert is easy and can save time. For instance, set up a Google alert at https://www.google.com/alerts. Type your query in the box at the top, then click “Create Alert.”

steps.headline: Watch out for “Like” and “Share” social media scams.
steps.description: Don’t fall for scams that offer giveaways if you like or share a social media page. Simply liking or sharing a page won’t enter you into a contest. Always check social media accounts for blue verified check marks, and look out for suspicious errors, such as strange punctuation, typos, and posts with low-budget photo and video. Scams urging you to like or share a page start by posting popular content, such as a Disney giveaway. Unsuspecting people like and share the page, and it goes viral. Once it’s accumulated enough likes and shares, scammers switch out the old content with malware.

steps.headline: Avoid clicking banner ads that promote giveaways.
steps.description: Banner ads detailing a Disney giveaway could actually be links to malware or viruses. Never click on an unknown or untrustworthy link. Instead, check to see if the ad lists a company sponsoring the contest. If it doesn’t list a sponsoring company, it’s probably a scam. If it lists a well-known company or organization, check their official website to verify that they’re sponsoring a contest. Then submit an entry through their website. If the ad lists a company you’ve never heard of, find their Better Business Bureau listing at https://www.bbb.org.

steps.headline: Don’t pay any upfront fees.
steps.description: A legitimate contest will never require you to pay any upfront fees, even for taxes or shipping and handling. Additionally, never enter your credit or debit card numbers or any other payment information into a contest entry form.

steps.headline: Don’t deposit any checks a scammer sends you.
steps.description: Some contest scammers send participants a check, which the scammers claim is to cover taxes or fees. A legitimate contest or giveaway will never send you a check, so don’t fall for any check fraud scams. A scammer might ask you to cash a check and send the money to them to cover taxes and fees. However, you'll have to pay back the bank once they discover you've deposited a bad check.

steps.headline: Make sure you’re eligible before filling out an entry.
steps.description: You don't want to win a prize only to find that you’re not eligible to claim it. Always check age, location, and other demographic requirements before entering a contest. Eligibility limitations could also work in your favor, provided you fit the requirements. Contests open to certain age groups or locations can reduce the number of eligible participants and increase your chances of winning.

steps.headline: Have every eligible member of your family submit entries.
steps.description: Recruit your spouse, kids, and other family members or, with their permission, submit entries on their behalf. If you’re trying to score a trip for a group of friends, have all of your buddies enter the contest. The more entries you submit, the better your chances of winning.

steps.headline: Set alarms to remind you to submit daily entries.
steps.description: Some contests allow participants to submit at least 1 entry per day. Set a daily reminder on your phone to ensure you don’t miss an opportunity to enter.

steps.headline: Try using multiple phones to win radio contests.
steps.description: Being a radio contest’s lucky caller is tough, but there are a few tricks that could boost your shot at winning. Recruit friends or relatives to call the contest number from their phones. If you want to go all out, buy an inexpensive prepaid phone to double your chances of being the lucky caller. Be sure to program the radio station’s number into your phone so you can quickly call when the contest begins. Brush up on your music knowledge if the contest involves trivia, such as questions about current chart toppers.

text: Finding Contests and Sweepstakes Check Disney Parks’ official website regularly. Disney Parks periodically posts contest and sweepstakes, so bookmark https://disneyparks.disney.go.com on your web browser. Find the tab marked “Special Offers” to browse discounts and sweepstakes. You can also type keywords such as “Disneyland,” “contests,” and “sweepstakes” in the search bar. Follow Disney Parks on social media. Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter are also great ways to find out about official Disney-sponsored giveaways. Just make sure the social media account you’re following is actually affiliated with Disney. It should be free of spelling and grammatical errors and have a blue verified check mark next to its name. Find a full list of official Disney Parks social media accounts at https://disneyparks.disney.go.com/social-media. Check reputable websites that list contests every week. Websites such as MouseSavers.com compile current Disney contests and sweepstakes. Make sure any contest-listing websites you browse only list contests sponsored by Disney or a major corporation or organization. Check “About” pages for information about how websites vet their listings. Contest listings are typically updated weekly, so check back once a week. Look for contests and offers on official tourism association websites. Official tourism associations frequently offer discounts and occasionally run contests. The official tourism association for Anaheim, CA, which is where Disneyland is located, is https://visitanaheim.org. You can also search for associations affiliated with other Disney park locations. Enter the location plus “official tourism association.” Check websites’ “About” sections to ensure they specify that they’re a city’s official tourism organization. Official tourism organization websites typically have a “Discounts” tab on the home page’s menu bar. You can also enter “special offer,” “contest,” or “sweepstakes” into the search bar. Set up search engine alerts. You could search every day for giveaways sponsored by Disney, reputable websites, travel companies, or local TV and radio stations. However, setting up a search alert is easy and can save time. For instance, set up a Google alert at https://www.google.com/alerts. Type your query in the box at the top, then click “Create Alert.” Avoiding Scams Watch out for “Like” and “Share” social media scams. Don’t fall for scams that offer giveaways if you like or share a social media page. Simply liking or sharing a page won’t enter you into a contest. Always check social media accounts for blue verified check marks, and look out for suspicious errors, such as strange punctuation, typos, and posts with low-budget photo and video. Once it’s accumulated enough likes and shares, scammers switch out the old content with malware. Avoid clicking banner ads that promote giveaways. Banner ads detailing a Disney giveaway could actually be links to malware or viruses. Never click on an unknown or untrustworthy link. Instead, check to see if the ad lists a company sponsoring the contest. If it doesn’t list a sponsoring company, it’s probably a scam. If it lists a well-known company or organization, check their official website to verify that they’re sponsoring a contest. Then submit an entry through their website. If the ad lists a company you’ve never heard of, find their Better Business Bureau listing at https://www.bbb.org. Don’t pay any upfront fees. A legitimate contest will never require you to pay any upfront fees, even for taxes or shipping and handling. Additionally, never enter your credit or debit card numbers or any other payment information into a contest entry form. Don’t deposit any checks a scammer sends you. Some contest scammers send participants a check, which the scammers claim is to cover taxes or fees. A legitimate contest or giveaway will never send you a check, so don’t fall for any check fraud scams. A scammer might ask you to cash a check and send the money to them to cover taxes and fees. However, you'll have to pay back the bank once they discover you've deposited a bad check. Increasing Your Chances of Winning Make sure you’re eligible before filling out an entry. You don't want to win a prize only to find that you’re not eligible to claim it. Always check age, location, and other demographic requirements before entering a contest. Eligibility limitations could also work in your favor, provided you fit the requirements. Contests open to certain age groups or locations can reduce the number of eligible participants and increase your chances of winning. Have every eligible member of your family submit entries. Recruit your spouse, kids, and other family members or, with their permission, submit entries on their behalf. If you’re trying to score a trip for a group of friends, have all of your buddies enter the contest. The more entries you submit, the better your chances of winning. Set alarms to remind you to submit daily entries. Some contests allow participants to submit at least 1 entry per day. Set a daily reminder on your phone to ensure you don’t miss an opportunity to enter. Try using multiple phones to win radio contests. Being a radio contest’s lucky caller is tough, but there are a few tricks that could boost your shot at winning. Recruit friends or relatives to call the contest number from their phones. Be sure to program the radio station’s number into your phone so you can quickly call when the contest begins. Brush up on your music knowledge if the contest involves trivia, such as questions about current chart toppers.
